Paragraph: The OFET mobilities are calculated in the saturation regime using the following equation : 2 , where W and L are the channel width and length , respectively , C i is the capacitance per unit area of the insulation layer. Linear plot of I ds 1 / 2 vs V gs deduced from the I ds vs V gs measurement. These devices show characteristics of a typical p-channel transistor with good drain - current Modulation , well - defined linear , and saturation regions ( Figure 2 ). The summary of the performances is provided in Table 1. I ds = ( W / 2L ) × μ × C i ( V gs - V th ) The OFET device using as-cast PCDTBT films without thermal annealing exhibits a hole mobility of 2.2 × 10^-4 cm^2 / V°s with an on / off current ratio ( I on / I off ) of 4.44 × 10^3 . For PCDTBT thin films after annealing at evaluated temperatures , the mobilities are not markedly improved , implying that the PCDTBT thin films remain nearly amorphous for both as-cast and annealing at high temperature. On the other hand , it is found that the unannealed thin films of PCDSeBT exhibit a slightly higher mobility of μ h = 5.1 × 10^-4 cm^2 / V°s , compared with that of pristine PCDTBT. Interestingly , in contrast , as the PCDSeBT thin films are annealed at a temperature of 120 and 150 °C , the mobilities are systematically improved up to 1.0 × 10^-3 cm^2 / V°s ( Figure 2b ) , which is about 1 order of magnitude higher than that of PCDTBT , possibly due to increased interpolymer chain contact induced by Se°°°Se interactions with the thermal annealing process. To gain a better understanding of the influence of the thermal annealing , the crystallinity and molecular organization of PCDTBT and PCDSeBT thin films were investigated by Xray diffraction ( XRD ) , both before and after annealing at 150 °C . Both the as-cast and annealed PCDTBT thin films fail to reveal any defined scattering patterns ( Figure 3a ) , indicating the macroscopically disordered , amorphous structure. In the case of PCDSeBT , the as-cast thin films show very weak diffractions ( Figure 3b ). Upon thermal annealing , the primary peak at 4.42 ° , corresponding to a d-spacing of 19.99 Å , progressively intensifies and the secondary broad peak at ∼ 21.1 ° ( d = 4.21 Å ) that is probably related to π-π stacking becomes visible ( Figure 3b ). On the basis of these XRD results , we can conclude that the oriented microstructure of the as-cast PCDSeBT thin films is kinetically limited but the polymer chains reorganize to ordered lamellar packing structures upon annealing. This observation is a plausible explanation for the sudden rise in mobility of PCDSeBT as a function of the thermal annealing.

| as-cast PCDTBT films |
| PCDTBT thin films |

| as-cast PCDTBT thin films |
| annealed PCDTBT thin films |
| PCDSeBT thin films |
| π-π stacking |
| lamellar packing structures |

Paragraph: The OFET mobilities are calculated in the saturation regime using the following equation : 2 , where W and L are the channel width and length , respectively , C i is the capacitance per unit area of the insulation layer. Linear plot of I ds 1 / 2 vs V gs deduced from the I ds vs V gs measurement. These devices show characteristics of a typical p-channel transistor with good drain - current Modulation , well - defined linear , and saturation regions ( Figure 2 ). The summary of the performances is provided in Table 1. I ds = ( W / 2L ) × μ × C i ( V gs - V th ) The OFET device using as-cast PCDTBT films without thermal annealing exhibits a hole mobility of 2.2 × 10^-4 cm^2 / V°s with an on / off current ratio ( I on / I off ) of 4.44 × 10^3 . For PCDTBT thin films after annealing at evaluated temperatures , the mobilities are not markedly improved , implying that the PCDTBT thin films remain nearly amorphous for both as-cast and annealing at high temperature. On the other hand , it is found that the unannealed thin films of PCDSeBT exhibit a slightly higher mobility of μ h = 5.1 × 10^-4 cm^2 / V°s , compared with that of pristine PCDTBT. To gain a better understanding of the influence of the thermal annealing , the crystallinity and molecular organization of PCDTBT and PCDSeBT thin films were investigated by Xray diffraction ( XRD ) , both before and after annealing at 150 °C . In the case of PCDSeBT , the as-cast thin films show very weak diffractions ( Figure 3b ). On the basis of these XRD results , we can conclude that the oriented microstructure of the as-cast PCDSeBT thin films is kinetically limited but the polymer chains reorganize to ordered lamellar packing structures upon annealing. Let's think step by step.

Here are the property names of materials mentioned in the paragraph:

| Property Name |
| --- |
| OFET mobilities |
| channel width |
| channel length |
| capacitance per unit area of the insulation layer |
| drain current |
| on/off current ratio |
| hole mobility |
| d-spacing |

The "OFET mobilities" are the field-effect mobilities of organic thin-film transistors (OFETs) that are calculated in the saturation regime. The "channel width" and "channel length" are geometrical properties of the transistor channel. The "capacitance per unit area of the insulation layer" is a property related to the insulating layer in the OFET device. The "drain current" is the electrical current flowing through the transistor channel between the drain and source electrodes. The "on/off current ratio" is the ratio of the drain current in the "on" state (when the gate voltage is above the threshold voltage) to the drain current in the "off" state (when the gate voltage is below the threshold voltage). The "hole mobility" is a measure of how fast holes (positive charge carriers) can move through the organic semiconductor material. The "d-spacing" is a measure of the distance between diffraction planes in a crystal lattice, which can be obtained from X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements.

Please remove entities that do not clearly refer to "Property name of material" and present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Property Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Here are the property names of materials mentioned in the paragraph:

| Property Name |
| --- |
| OFET mobilities |
| capacitance per unit area of the insulation layer |
| drain current |
| on/off current ratio |
| hole mobility |
| d-spacing |

I have removed the "channel width" and "channel length" as they are geometrical properties rather than material properties. I have also removed "π-π stacking" as it is a phenomenon rather than a property.
